Project Description  Good transport infrastructure is recognized as a prerequisite and 
foundation on which governments can plan and implement their 
economic and social development programs. The Project forms 
part  of  the  Bangkok-Phnom  Penh-Ho  Chi  Min  City-Vung  Tau 
Road Improvement Project (Greater Mekong Subregion [GMS] 
Regional  Highway  R1),  which  is  one  of  10  high-priority 
subregional  road  projects  identified  under  a  Subregional 
Transport  Sector  Study  completed  in  1994.  GMS  Regional 
Highway R1 is a core road infrastructure element of the GMS 
Southern Economic Corridor, a priority development corridor that 
connects  central  Thailand  to  southern  Viet  Nam  through 
Cambodia and that will increase integration of the Cambodian 
economy  with  the  economies  of  Thailand  and  Viet  Nam.  The 
Project  will  rehabilitate  national  road  (NR)  5  and  NR6,  and 
reconstruct about 45 bridges between Siem Reap and Poipet on 
the border with Thailand, thus (i) completing a critical missing link 
in  GMS  Regional  Highway  R1,  (ii)  establishing  direct  highway 
connection between Thailand and the rapidly developing tourism 
center in Siem Reap and Angkor Wat, and (iii) providing access to 
northwestern Cambodia by completing the primary road network 
around  Tonle  Sap.  The  Project  will  also  reconstruct  about  50 
bridges on approximately 200 kilometers of the northern loop of 
NR56 and NR68, linking the towns of Svey Chek, Thmar Puok, 
and Samrong to the national road network, and providing access 
to large rural areas in the provinces of Banteay Meanchey, Oddar 
Meanchey, and parts of Siem Reap province. The Project will 
initiate a process of reform for the Ministry of Public Works and 
Transport (MPWT). An associated activity has been developed 
under  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  to 
mainstream  pro-poor  appropriate  technological  solutions  for 
roadworks in Cambodia. 
   
Rationale  Economic  cooperation  among  the  six  GMS  countries  is 
considered a major contributor to sustainable economic and social 
development, including poverty reduction, in the region. Efficient 
transport  that  provides  improved  access  is  key  to  increased 
subregional  trade  and  tourism,  economic  development,  and 
poverty reduction. Investments in roads in Cambodia are part of a 
continuing  program  to  reestablish  the  country’s  transport 
infrastructure after nearly 30 years of civil strife. The Project will

thus  assist  balanced  economic  and  social  development  in 
Cambodia through improvement of part of a major subregional 
transport  corridor  in  the  country.  Specifically,  the  Project  will 
(i) improve subregional economic cooperation via realization of 
the Southern Economic Corridor; (ii) ensure flood-free connectivity 
to  the  northwestern  parts  of  the  country;  (iii) support  national 
economic  development  and  local  employment  generation  by 
facilitating the development of tourism; and (iv) improve access in 
northwest Cambodia to social services, markets, and employment 
opportunities by connecting primary and secondary roads to the 
tertiary  network  in  the  project  area,  thereby  supporting  the 
infrastructure  currently  being  rehabilitated  under  other  projects 
financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the area. 
   
Objectives  The overall objectives of the Project are to promote economic 
activities and facilitate trade among Cambodia, Thailand, and Viet 
Nam and to improve the prospects for poverty reduction along the 
Southern Economic Corridor. The Project will: (i) together with 
other  ongoing  and  planned  investments  funded  by  other 
development  partners,  promote  national  and  subregional 
economic  growth  by  reducing  the  cost  and  increasing  the 
reliability of transport, which will also encourage the fast-growing 
tourism  industry  and  subregional  trade,  and  promote  general 
economic  growth;  (ii) reduce  poverty  by  providing  all-year,  all-
weather  access  to  employment  opportunities,  markets,  and 
growth  centers;  (iii) improve  social  conditions  by  providing  all-
year,  all-weather  access  to  education  and  health;  (iv) promote 
private  sector  participation  and  strengthen  the  domestic  road-
contracting  industry  by  providing  opportunities  in  road 
construction  and  maintenance;  (v) work  with  an  experienced 
nongovernment  organization  (NGO)  under  the  national  human 
immunodeficiency  virus/acquired  immunodeficiency  syndrome 
(HIV/AIDS) framework to support efforts to control the disease 
and create awareness of it; (vi) initiate a process of reform for 
MPWT,  particularly  for  the  road  sector  in  which  asset 
management and transparency must be a guiding theme; and 
(vii) establish effective road maintenance management and road 
maintenance financing systems.

Project Benefits and  The main quantifiable benefits of the Project consist of (i) savings 
Beneficiaries  in vehicle operating costs, (ii) vehicle and passenger time cost 
savings, and (iii) benefits from traffic generated by the reduction in 
transport costs. The subregional benefits are associated with the 
road’s contribution to increased integration of the economies of 
Thailand,  Cambodia,  and  Viet Nam  that  will  enable  the

surplus benefits; income generated by additional tourism; income 
from  increased  agricultural  activity;  and  social  benefits  from 
improved access to schools, medical facilities, and other social 
services.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  The major risks to the Project relate to achievement of expected 
traffic  levels,  adherence  to  construction  schedules,  quality  of 
works, and proper selection of consultants and contractors. With 
the  growing  experience  of  MPWT  in  the  construction  and 
maintenance of externally financed roads and the engagement of 
qualified construction supervision consultants, the risks to timely 
and  successful  implementation  of  the  Project  will  be  greatly 
reduced. Particular attention will be paid to the formulation of and 
adherence to design standards, and the implementation of the 
resettlement plan so that appropriate compensation to affected 
persons is effected prior to start of civil works. The reorganization 
of  MPWT  is  a  continuing  and  evolving  process  that  will  also 
require close attention and commitment from the Government to 
ensure that a clear reform program is implemented during the 
project period.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
and administration of a proposed loan from the OPEC Fund for International Development to the 
Kingdom  of  Cambodia  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion:  Cambodia  Road  Improvement 
Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, ISSUES, AND DIRECTIONS 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Background 
2.  The Project forms part of the Bangkok-Phnom Penh-Ho Chi Minh City-Vung Tau Road 
Improvement Project (Greater Mekong Subregion [GMS] Regional Highway R1), which is one of 
10 high-priority subregional road projects identified in a Subregional Transport Sector Study 
completed in 1994.1 The GMS R1 forms the core of the Southern Economic Corridor that links 
central Thailand, Cambodia, and southern Viet Nam. The GMS R1 project was endorsed by the 
Fourth  GMS  Ministerial  Conference  in  1994  and  reaffirmed  at  the  10th  GMS  Ministerial 
Conference in November 2001. The Project will rehabilitate a 50-kilometer (km) section of 
national road (NR) 5, thereby completing the Bangkok-Phnom Penh-Ho Chi Minh City-Vung Tau 
GMS R1, which together with ongoing and planned improvements along NR1 between Phnom 
Penh and Ho Chi Minh City, and improvement and bridge replacement on NR5 and NR6 
financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Government of Japan, and the World 
Bank, will complete the southern leg of the Southern Economic Corridor.2 At the national level, 
the Project responds to the Government’s infrastructure development emphasis on improving 
the national and provincial road network to allow more effective access to the rural areas and 
induce economic growth. The roads covered by the Project lie in the northwestern part of the 
country and include important strategic and rural access links that address trade and poverty 
reduction issues. Northwestern Cambodia is one of the poorest regions of the country and 
critically needs postconflict reconstruction to enable resumption of economic activities. It is also 
the region containing Angkor Wat, which forms the basis for a rapidly growing tourism industry, 
and is the entry and exit point for most of the trade between Cambodia and Thailand. The 
Project Framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
3.  Years of civil strife have led to a widespread and severe deterioration of Cambodia’s 
transport infrastructure. The condition of the transport system continues to restrict the economic 
and social development of the country, despite the fact that much has been achieved in terms of 
rehabilitation and reconstruction of the transport system during the past 10 years. Notably, a 
core network of national roads, comprising approximately one third of the primary road network, 
has been reestablished, with support from ADB and other development partners. A list of 
external  assistance  activities  for  major  roads  is  in  Appendix  2.  The  main  seaport  at 
Sihanoukville, and the airports at Phnom Penh and Siem Reap, have also been rehabilitated

2.  Road Network 
4.  The  Cambodian  road  network  covers  about  35,500  km,  including  approximately 
4,000 km of national roads, 3,500 km of provincial roads, and 28,000 km of rural and strategic 
roads. The roads have a significant number of bridges, about 4,000 on the primary roads alone. 
Most of the road network is dilapidated and large parts of the country are effectively isolated 
during the wet season. Most bridges are seriously damaged or failed. The Ministry of Public 
Works and Transport (MPWT) considers that at least half of the primary road network and 
nearly all of the secondary and tertiary roads are in need of urgent repair, rehabilitation, or 
reconstruction. Road condition surveys in 2002 confirm that 28% of the network is in good or fair 
condition,  35%  in  poor  condition,  28%  in  bad  condition,  and  6%  under  reconstruction  or 
rehabilitation. An assessment of the road sector is presented in Appendix 3. Road transport is 
the dominant mode of transport within Cambodia, accounting for 65% of all passenger traffic 
and 70% of all cargo traffic, with rail, river, and air transport sharing the rest. Subregional traffic 
is dominated by road and river modes catering to cargo traffic, and air and road transport 
catering to passenger traffic. Subregional traffic is still modest, but Cambodia and its neighbors 
are making great efforts at promoting and easing international traffic, developing effective cross-
border agreements to facilitate movement of goods and people, adopting uniform navigational 
rules on the Mekong River, and developing border crossing infrastructure and border access 
roads. 
 
5.  Substantial  parts  of  Cambodia’s  primary  road  network  form  part  of  designated 
subregional road transport corridors, principal among those being GMS Regional Highway 1 
(also known as Asian Highway 1) connecting Bangkok, Phnom Penh, and Ho Chi Minh City via 
NR5 and NR1 in Cambodia. The road section from Poipet on the Cambodia-Thailand border to 
Sisophon represents the last remaining gap on GMS Regional Highway 1 to be rehabilitated. 
 
6.  The Project has enormous potential to facilitate the movement of goods and people 
between Cambodia and Thailand, given the fast-growing economic interaction that is taking 
place between the two countries. Cross-border trade between Cambodia and Thailand along 
NR5 has expanded significantly over the past few years. The value of recorded cross-border 
trade  through  the  Poipet-Aranyaphathet  border  crossing  increased  considerably  from 
$27.0 million in 1992 to $238.0 million in 1999, an annual compound growth rate of 36%. Much 
of this growth was caused by the rerouting of trade from other entry points to Poipet, reflecting 
the improvements in road conditions on NR5 and the restoration of peace in the area. Thus, the 
share of total bilateral trade routed through Poipet increased from 14% in 1992 to 65% in 1999 
(Figure 1). Cross-border overland tourism from Thailand has also become more common in 
recent years, with 73,000 persons passing through the border into Cambodia during the first 6 
months of 2002, a figure that is expected to increase significantly when the road is improved. 
NR6 takes the network through Siem Reap, which is the site of Angkor Wat, a World Heritage

3.  Government Policy for the Sector 
7.  Under the April 2001 draft Second Five-Year Socioeconomic Development Plan 2001–
2005 (SEDP II), the policy objective of rehabilitating and maintaining transport infrastructure is 
to be achieved by giving priority to road rehabilitation and to improvements in road operations 
and maintenance capability. The Five-Year Road Master Plan (2000–2005) has three main 
aims:  (i) to  rehabilitate  and  reconstruct  the  main  national  roads,  thereby  improving  land 
transport throughout the nation; (ii) to build road links to neighboring countries, thereby opening 
up some of the more remote areas of the country to international trade and tourism; and (iii) to 
develop a sustainable road maintenance program, thereby ensuring that investment in road 
rehabilitation and reconstruction generates sustainable benefits. 
 
8.  Supportive and additional aims are to (i) provide all provincial capitals, tourist areas, and 
major growth areas with all-weather road access; (ii) ease traffic congestion in and around 
Phnom Penh by undertaking a study of options for traffic calming solutions (such as bypasses), 
with a view to formulating and implementing appropriate projects; (iii) undertake emergency 
rehabilitation of provincial roads in order to better link provincial towns with district capitals and 
urban areas; (iv) make supplementary investments in bridges and ferry sites; (v) ensure as far 
as possible that the maintenance of designated national and provincial roads, bridges, and 
ferries, and the control and regulation of vehicles, be self-financing from vehicle registration 
charges, tolls, international transit charges, fuel levies, or other related taxes and duties; and 
(vi) ensure that as far as possible, all provincial, urban, and rural roads are maintained from 
locally generated funds. 
 
9.  A draft Traffic Act is pending at the National Assembly and a proposed subdecree on 
roads is being developed by MPWT. The draft Act contains penal provisions, traffic rules, 
technical standards for signs and signals, technical standards for vehicle components, and other

4 
elements. However, there are no guidelines for road construction and repair, road transport, 
driver training, the information system, and other important issues that should be included in the 
subdecree. Given the fact that motorization and road-borne trade are increasing significantly, 
the road sector will be the primary focus of policy, legislative and institutional support, and as 
such will require an effective enabling environment that should be provided through the Road 
Act.  
 
4.  Poverty in Northwestern Cambodia 
10.  The provinces of Siem Reap, Banteay Meanchey, and Oddar Meanchey in northwestern 
Cambodia, where the Project is located, have received minimal development assistance in the 
past  because  of  war  and  insecurity,  and  suffer  from  a  high  incidence  of  poverty  and 
vulnerability, as shown in a 1999 World Food Program poverty mapping study. Poverty is 
widespread in the area with severe problems of accessibility during the rainy season. This is 
especially  evident  for  Oddar  Meanchey.  The  study  suggests  that  no  less  than  60%  of 
households suffer from food deficiency. Although there is some scope for foraging, hunting, and 
gathering to supplement precarious livelihoods, most households find their food stocks depleted 
within 4 months of harvest. It is estimated that 40–60% of households are below the official 
poverty line. Government services, such as health and education, rarely reach the interior and 
tend to be restricted to peri-urban areas. Family spacing is nonexistent and reproductive health 
services are largely inaccessible due to the widely dispersed nature of the population and long 
travel distances, especially within Oddar Meanchey. 
 
11.  The provinces of Siem Reap, Banteay Meanchey, and Oddar Meanchey are some of the 
most backward in Cambodia in terms of farming practices, physical infrastructure, and social, 
health, and utility services. Drinking water is usually obtained from rainwater stored in open 
depressions,  clay  pots,  or  from  bore-wells;  latrines  are  virtually  nonexistent.  Clinics  and 
hospitals are located in the district headquarters, entailing long travel times and high costs. 
While many households have cattle for tillage and transport, motorcycles and television sets are 
very few. Generally, housing conditions are very poor, especially along NR56 and NR68 and in 
areas further away from the main centers. Access to basic health and education services is 
fragmentary, owing to the relative remoteness of the villages and populations living in the 
northwestern area served by NR56 and NR68. Road conditions are extremely poor with virtually 
all bridges broken or unusable. Owing to lack of continuous access, the traffic consists of 
motorbikes, animal carts, and taxi-vans. Transport costs are predictably high as travel time is 
long. 
 
12.  The overall poverty estimate for the project area is about 40%. However, there are 
significant variations, with the areas serviced by better roads displaying the lowest poverty level 
(25%), while NR56 and areas serviced by poor roads have very high poverty levels (over 60%). 
Thus, quite apart from relatively high poverty levels in the project area compared with the 
national situation, there are deep pockets of extensive poverty, much of which is related to the 
relative physical remoteness and poor infrastructure in the area. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Asian Development Bank’s Goals and Objectives for Cambodia 
13.  The  three  priority  areas  of  the  ADB  country  strategy  and  program  (CSP)—rural 
economic development, human resources development, and private sector development—and 
the 10 sectors through which the strategy is to be implemented, remain valid in light of the 
current development situation. The 2001 and 2002 operational programs constituted a first

5 
phase of implementing the strategy. The program of lending and nonlending assistance for 
2003–2005 constitutes a second phase, substantially completing considerable work in the 10 
sectors.  The  CSP  has  been  further  strengthened  by  provision  of  a  sharper  focus  on  the 
implications of the state reform program—especially decentralization of public administration—
and by enhancement of the poverty impact of sector interventions to support the Government’s 
goal of achieving its poverty reduction targets, in light of projected gross domestic product  
growth.  
 
2.  Lessons Learned 
14.  Given the limited duration of ADB assistance to Cambodia, it is still somewhat early to 
systematically assess the impact of its interventions. However, as ADB was the first major 
funding agency to return to Cambodia, its interventions came at a critical time and undoubtedly 
have had a positive impact. The Special Rehabilitation Assistance Loan4 is the only project that 
has been postevaluated. The project, which was rated successful, had several components to 
support the transport, energy, agriculture, and education sectors. The performances of both the 
Government and ADB were also rated successful. 
 
15.  For the road sector, the principal lesson thus far is that of the need to develop more 
effective  network  planning  mechanisms,  including  road  classification  and  referencing,  road

as  procurement  and  tendering  documentation,  financial  management,  and  performance

contracts,  contract  management  will  have  to  be  significantly  improved  through  appropriate

improve road quality, which itself needs improvement in the areas of site supervision and 
materials testing standards. At the institutional level, MPWT needs to make more effort to retain 
trained staff for effective project supervision. Enforcement of truck overloading policies needs to 
be strengthened, as well as roadworthiness inspections and collection of penalties. Road safety 
improvements  should  be  addressed  with  more  extensive  awareness  and  driver  training 
campaigns. Mine awareness programs should also be expanded.  
 
16.  Recent experience with resettlement issues has provided valuable lessons, including the 
necessity for (i) properly compensating people for loss of land use in the right-of-way (ROW) 
and appropriately valued replacement cost for structures; (ii) providing compensation for lost 
income;  (iii) appropriately  conducted  internal  and  external  monitoring  and  reporting; 
(iv) separating  resettlement  planning  and  implementation  from  regulatory  agencies;  and 
(v) building local capacity for resettlement planning, implementation, and monitoring.

B.  Components and Outputs 
1.  Civil Works 
a.  NR5 and NR6 
18.  The Project will rehabilitate a road section of about 150 km of highway and about 45 
bridges on NR5 and NR6. NR5 and NR6 connect three major towns in the area: Siem Reap, 
Sisophon (both provincial capitals), and Poipet (the primary border crossing between Cambodia 
and Thailand). From Poipet there is a direct highway connection to Bangkok, and from Sisophon 
and Siem Reap there are direct highway connections to Phnom Penh, running east and west of 
Tonle Sap, respectively. Siem Reap on NR6 is the center of an established and growing tourism 
industry based on Angkor Wat and many other historic temples in the area. NR6 connects Siem 
Reap to the southern part of Viet Nam through Phnom Penh, while NR5 also links Cambodia 
with Thailand and southern Viet Nam.  
 
19.  The road traverses primarily agricultural land. Only a few villages are located at the 
roadside, the majority of the population living in the hinterland along the secondary and tertiary 
road network. The agricultural potential of the area is high, but presently underutilized due to 
widespread  unexploded  ordnance  (UXO),  which  also  hinders  the  resettlement  of  people 
displaced  during  the  years  of  civil  strife.  The  ongoing  ADB-financed  Northwestern  Rural 
Development Project (NRDP),5 which is located in the general area of influence of the proposed 
Project, includes a significant component of rural roads rehabilitation. The rural roads all link into 
the project road, which form the spine of the local road networks and provide the connection to 
higher-growth centers. Full realization of the intended benefits from NRDP will depend on 
rehabilitation of the highways that provide access. 
 
20.  The current condition of the project roads is very poor, with most of the pavements 
completely failed and covered with graded dirt. These sections of the road are impassable 
during the wet season. The road has a large number of cross-drainage structures (over 100 
culverts and 50 bridges) that are located mainly between Sisophon and Siem Reap. The road 
borders the Tonle Sap floodplain and is crossed by a large number of tributaries to the Tonle 
Sap.  Beyond  Sisophon  the  land  is  elevated  and  dry.  Most  bridges  were  either  severely 
damaged or demolished during the years of civil strife and many have been replaced with 
temporary Bailey bridges. The Bailey bridges are narrow and many are partly failed. The road 
embankment  is  significantly  deteriorated  in  some  places.  During  the  wet  season,  certain 
sections are often inundated. 
 
21.  Present traffic on the project road consists primarily of pedestrians, cycles, motorcycles, 
cars  and  pickups,  trucks  and  heavy  truck-trailer  combinations,  and  some  buses.  The 
rehabilitated road will generate significant traffic serving local traffic needs, the rapidly growing 
tourism centered around Siem Reap, and subregional trade between Cambodia and Thailand.

2.  Resettlement Plan 
26.   The resettlement study (presented in Supplementary Appendix A) has shown that the

3.  Poverty Reduction Monitoring Program 
27.  A detailed socioeconomic survey (presented in Supplementary Appendix B) was carried 
out to establish baseline conditions to enable poverty monitoring and impact evaluation studies 
to be conducted during and after project completion. The baseline data include demographic 
and  health  information,  with  a  particular  focus  on  HIV/AIDS.  The  survey  has  established 
benchmarks in terms of land and asset ownership, labor use, migration patterns, incomes and 
expenditures, access to services and credit, farm production, tenancy arrangements, conditions 
of transport infrastructure, and access to common property resources.  
 
28.  Under the Project, two surveys will be carried out. The first survey will be conducted 
within 2 years of initiation of construction while the second survey will be conducted at project 
completion. The first survey will allow monitoring of socioeconomic conditions along the lines of 
the baseline survey, and the second will enable impact assessment analysis. The objective of 
the surveys is to generate panel data at two points in time to enable comparison with the 
baseline. In principle, the methodology followed should be similar to the baseline approach. This 
will involve division of the project area into three categories for sampling purposes: (i) in the 
vicinity of a good section of the primary road, (ii) in areas close to a poor section of the primary 
road, and (iii) areas within the influence area of the loop section. Villages along a 3–5 km radius 
from the road sections will be identified and 10–20% sampled at the first stage. A total of 250–
300 households are planned sampled at random from those villages. It is expected that the 
Government will conduct a comprehensive follow-up survey after 2–3 years of completion of 
civil works to establish in more detail the poverty reduction impacts of the Project.

1.  Strengthening the Ministry of Public Works and Transport 
 
a.  Strategic Planning and Project Management in the Ministry of Public 
Works and Transport 
 
29.  The current planning process at MPWT needs considerable strengthening. Governance 
is obviously an issue. The Department of Planning (DOP) prepares overall plans by compiling 
proposals  received  by  the  planning  units  from  other  MPWT  departments.  However,  these 
proposals  are  not  based  on  proper  evaluation  processes,  particularly  economic  or  social 
analyses. ADB earlier provided technical assistance8 for training to core DOP staff in transport 
planning and related subjects to equip them with basic skills in undertaking strategic, multimodal 
planning on a self-sustaining basis and to develop sector policies. Although some capacity was 
developed among DOP staff, DOP has had few opportunities to use the acquired skills owing to 
budget  and  administrative  constraints,  and  to  turnover  of  trained  staff.  The  core  planning 
functions, i.e., policy formulation, traffic forecasting, preparing investment programs, annual 
budgeting, and database development and maintenance, are not being implemented, owing to 
organizational inefficiencies, the location of DOP in the organizational hierarchy, and a shortage 
of funds to implement change. Appendix 5 shows the current MPWT organization chart. The 
chart sets DOP at the bottom of the hierarchy within the General Department of Administrative 
Services, resulting in a weakening of DOP authority and communication flows to other MPWT 
departments.  
 
30.  There is thus a clear need to move DOP from the General Department of Administrative 
Services closer to MPWT management, so increasing direct accountability to the Minister of 
Public Works and Transport. Being directly accountable to the Minister, DOP’s primary role 
should be to provide technical advice to MPWT management on matters related to policy 
development and strategic planning. 
 
31.  Major rehabilitation works have been financed by external funds, and the projects are 
implemented by ad hoc project management units (PMUs)/project implementation units (PIUs) 
that  are  not  formally  within  the  MPWT  organizational  structure.  The  current  management 
approach  is  fragmented,  and  does  not  create  effective  responsibility  and  accountability  in 
MPWT.  The  establishment  of  PMUs/PIUs  for  each  individual  project  results  in  difficulty  in 
monitoring, adopting uniform technical standards, and sharing experiences on matters related to 
procurement and project management. An alternative solution for effectively managing external 
agency-funded projects will be formulated through reorganizing MPWT to address the emerging 
issues of coordination, efficiency, transparency, sustainability, and governance.

2.  Road Network Maintenance Strategy and Funding Mechanism 
38.  Although  a  first  step  has  been  made  by  establishing  the  Fund  for  Repair  and 
Maintenance of Roads (FRMR), it will be necessary for the Government to set up a road fund 
and  a  road  management  board  to  establish  fully  effective  road  maintenance  financing 
mechanisms. Similar approaches are under consideration and development by neighboring 
countries, namely the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) and Viet Nam. Drawing 
from experience gained to date in the Mekong region as well as in other countries throughout 
Africa, South America, and several republics of the former Soviet Union, earmarking of a portion 
of road user charges or setting up a road fund is by itself no solution. While this may solve part 
of the problem of security of funding source and dependability of funds for maintenance, a road 
fund  is  not  a  sufficient  condition  on  its  own  for  guaranteeing  a  sustainable  maintenance 
program. Clear institutional processes are required to plan and prioritize maintenance works 
effectively, as well as effective procedures for managing and disbursing funds.  
 
39.  The strategy for developing a more effective road fund will require (i) broadening and 
deepening the revenue base for the FRMR, (ii) ensuring accessibility to fund resources, and 
(iii) strengthening  and  building  the  institutional  structure  for  planning  and  delivery  of 
maintenance services. As an initial step, the General Department of Public Works within MPWT, 
together with the Contracts Office within the Road Infrastructure Department, could assume a 
driving  role  with  technical  assistance,  training,  and  support.  The  unit  would  evolve  into  a 
professional procurement structured group as institutional capacity is built up, with mirrored 
replication in the provincial departments. The intention is to reduce large overhead costs of 
traditional  bureaucratic  structures  and  provide  incentives  to  local  contractors  to  develop 
expertise and invest in their own equipment as the market for contracted maintenance and 
construction builds. Deepening the revenue base of the FRMR should include increases in the 
transport  tax,  particularly  for  heavy  commercial  vehicles,  annual  vehicle  registration  fees, 
gradual adjustments to fuel levies, and properly designed toll operations.  
 
40.  While developing the structure of a more substantive and effective road maintenance 
fund, which will likely take several years, it is important to ensure that the current funding levels 
and allocations are maintained and applied to maintenance, with no diversion to nonroad sector 
activities. This will require that the FRMR be dedicated solely to the road network, with principal 
allocation to the primary and secondary roads, and allowing for a specified allocation (10% as 
identified  under  the  Poverty  Partnership  Agreement)  to  the  rural  roads.  The  FRMR  thus 
becomes a network-directed source of maintenance financing.  
 
41.  To support the Government’s objective of promoting involvement of local contractors in 
roadworks,  international  contractors  are  being  encouraged  to  use  local  subcontractors  for 
certain types of works, with a view to enabling those local contractors to undertake routine 
maintenance of roads. Provisions for training local contractors and government officials in the 
planning and execution of contract-based road maintenance will be included in a proposal for 
mainstreaming poverty reduction approaches, that will be submitted to the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction (JFPR), supplemented by some training under the construction supervision 
services. The outputs envisage MPWT staff capable of planning, tendering for, and managing 
routine road maintenance contracts, and local contractors capable of bidding for, contracting, 
and implementing such contracts.

3.  HIV/AIDS Program 
42.  HIV/AIDS is spreading in Cambodia. HIV was first detected in Cambodia in 1991 and the 
first AIDS case diagnosed in 1993. In less than a decade, the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Cambodia 
became one of the most serious and fastest rising in the region. The main mode of transmission 
is currently through heterosexual sex. In 2000, HIV rates among sex workers ranged from 7.7% 
to 58% across provinces with an average of 31% among direct commercial workers and 16% 
among indirect sex workers. Sexually transmitted infection (STI) care and related interventions, 
combined with 100% condom use promotion and outreach for population groups in high-risk 
situations, have been identified as key components of HIV prevention in the National Strategy 
for  Prevention  and  Care  of  HIV/AIDS  and  STIs  for  2001–2005.  This  strategy  has  been 
implemented in the pilot province of Kampong Cham. Banteay Meanchey is one of five new 
target provinces for the “Triangle of HIV Prevention” to be strengthened by the end of 2004. A 
2000 survey indicated that approximately 2.8% of all Cambodians were then infected with HIV. 
 
43.  PMU, with advice and guidance from the social and environment unit in the proposed, 
repositioned Department of Planning of MPWT, will engage a suitably qualified agency (e.g., an 
NGO that is experienced in administering such programs in collaboration with MPWT) through 
local competitive bidding to implement a suitably designed campaign among road workers and 
in the local communities in the project-influenced area. The terms of reference for the executing 
agency includes using the “Toolkit for HIV Prevention” developed under ADB financing for use 
among mobile populations in the GMS. 
 
4.  Cross-Border Facilities 
44.  The GMS Cross-Border Agreement (footnote 7) is intended to (i) facilitate cross-border 
transport of goods and people among the countries in the subregion; (ii) harmonize legislation, 
regulations,  and  procedures  relating  to  cross-border  transport;  and  (iii) promote  multimodal 
transport. Currently, there are four signatories—Cambodia, Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
The People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Myanmar have indicated their willingness to become 
signatories. The Project links to the border crossing between Cambodia and Thailand at Poipet. 
This crossing is included as a GMS pilot site at which streamlined crossing procedures will be 
established  to  facilitate  the  development  of  cross-border  trade  and  mobility.  The  Project 
includes funding for the design and establishment of the physical facilities required for single-
stop, single-window procedures in Poipet.  
 
5.  Mainstreaming  Poverty  Reduction  Approaches  into  the  National  Road 
Network 
45.  There are a number of poverty-oriented gaps in the Government’s current road program. 
First, there is a need to connect the rural roads networks to the national road network by 
rehabilitating  the  intermediary  provincial  roads.  Second,  there  is  a  need  to  develop  more 
opportunities for and capacity of domestic private contractors who are capable and equipped to 
take on construction and maintenance work on the national and provincial roads. Third, more 
research needs to be done on road technologies best suited to Cambodia in terms of directly 
and  indirectly  achieving  poverty  reduction  goals,  including  compilation  and  review  of 
experiences from other countries. Finally, greater capacity is needed to train engineers, public 
sector  officials,  and  private  sector  contractors  and  consultants  in  road  technologies  and 
management.  
 
46.  A project concept, Mainstreaming Poverty Reduction Approaches into the National Road 
Network (MPRA), has been proposed for grant financing under JFPR to reduce poverty by

mainstreaming pro-poor appropriate technological and capability-building approaches into the 
road development programs of MPWT and the Ministry of Rural Development (MRD). The 
project will work toward maximizing the input of local entrepreneurs, materials, labor, and

employment and a long-term direct effect resulting from the provision of cost-effective tools for

47.  The MPRA is expected to be carried out in collaboration with the International Labour

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
63.  The  Project  will  promote  economic  growth  from  increased:  agricultural  production; 
tourism around the many historic temples throughout the project area; national and subregional 
trade; and local employment creation, which will help combat widespread poverty, especially in 
the rural areas. The Project will also provide efficient all-weather access to the rural areas in 
three provinces in northwestern Cambodia; to the provincial and commercial centers at Siem 
Reap, Sisophon, and Samrong; and to Poipet, Cambodia’s primary border crossing point with 
Thailand. By reducing road transport cost and improving access reliability, the Project will 
generate substantial direct economic benefits from future savings in vehicle operating costs, 
logistics,  and  road  maintenance.  It  will  also  relieve  the  isolation  of  remote  rural  areas  by 
reducing travel cost and time, and by eliminating seasonal disruption of traffic during the wet 
season, thus enabling continuous trade and economic exchange and undisrupted access to 
schools,9 health services,10 and other services in rural areas. Finally, the Project will enhance 
the impact of the Northwestern Rural Development Project by providing crucial interconnection 
of rural road networks without which “. . . the country will remain fragmented and the rural roads 
will, at best, lead to small provincial towns, isolating the poor population and limiting the benefits 
of trade available to them.”11 The main benefits of the Project are directly related to traffic, 
including (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, (ii) savings in vehicle and passenger time costs, 
and (iii) benefits from traffic generated by the reduction in transport costs. Additional benefits 
derived  from  generated  traffic  include  (iv) producer  surplus  benefits,  (v) additional  income 
engendered by tourism, (vi) additional income from the increased agricultural activity stemming 
from the rehabilitation of the road, and (vii) social benefits arising from better access to schools, 
medical facilities, and other social services. Derived subregional benefits that have not been 
quantified are long term, associated with the road’s contribution to increased integration of the 
economies of Thailand, Cambodia, and Viet Nam that, eventually, will enable the establishment 
of new and more efficient trading and transport patterns in the subregion. The economic internal 
rate of return (EIRR) is 30.7%. The economic analysis is in Supplementary Appendix E.

2.  Environmental Impacts 
65.  The Tonle Sap is the largest freshwater lake in Southeast Asia. It covers an area of 
approximately 250,000 ha in the dry season, and extends to 1,000,000 ha during the wet 
season. NR6 crosses a floodplain that is linked to the upper part of the Tonle Sap. Both the 
floodplain and the Tonle Sap are essential and linked components of the fisheries of the area. 
The huge wetland system with its habitat diversity supports one of the most productive fisheries 
in Asia. The road linking Siem Reap and Poipet is situated at about 10 m above sea level on a 
large area of the central plain that surrounds Tonle Sap. The plain rises imperceptibly at a 
gradient of about 0.03 % until it encounters the lower slopes of the Chuor Phnum Dangrek 
range that forms the divide between Cambodia and Thailand. The level of the Tonle Sap varies 
seasonally between 1.1 m and 10.0 m. As the road skirts the flood area, it is within the influence 
area, but is recognized as being in an area of least impact and hence generally environmentally 
benign. 
 
66.  Major  potential  environmental  impacts  are  (i) impacts  on  drainage;  (ii) impacts  on 
fishery;  (iii) noise  and  dust;  (iv) mismanagement  of  construction  materials  and  sites;  and 
(v) health and safety. Mitigation measures have been identified and can be implemented without 
difficulty. The initial environmental examination (IEE), together with an appropriately designed 
environmental management plan and monitoring programs, is considered sufficient to meet the 
environmental impact assessment requirements of the Project. The summary IEE is presented 
in Appendix 15. The full IEE is in Supplementary Appendix F. The Project will be implemented in 
accordance with ADB’s Environmental Guidelines for Infrastructure Projects. 
 
C.  Risks 
67.  The main risks associated with the Project are (i) lower than expected traffic levels; 
(ii) delayed  and  suboptimal  performance  of  contractors  and  supervision;  (iii) delay  in 
procurement and local counterpart funding; (iv) lack of adequate counterpart staff; (v) delayed or 
inadequate execution of mitigating measures, notably resettlement and HIV/AIDS reduction, and 
(v) insufficient or late implementation of institutional strengthening required to enable adequate 
future  management  and  maintenance  of  the  roads.  After  construction,  the  main  risks  are 
associated with the funding and management of maintenance of the roads, especially the loop 
road,  which  will  require  regular  grading  and  regraveling.  Considering  the  Government’s 
commitment to the Project and the project’s high economic return, the integrated benefits and 
impacts are expected to outweigh the costs, given the likelihood of the risks occurring.

A.  Introduction 
1.  The  road  network  in  Cambodia  covers  about  35,500  kilometers  (km),  including 
approximately 4,000 km of national roads, 3,500 km of provincial roads, and 28,000 km of rural 
and strategic roads. The roads have a significant number of bridges, about 4,000 on the 
national roads alone. The primary roads consists of National Roads 1-9, which are national 
highways that  extend from Phnom Penh to provincial capitals and the main access points to the 
country. Lesser national roads with 2-digit numbers are provincial highways that connect the 
provincial capitals and connect to minor border crossings and important domestic centers. The 
secondary (provincial roads) and tertiary (rural and strategic roads) serve local transport needs. 
The road network was mostly built before 1960. The general design standards thus cater to 
lighter traffic than current loads, with many existing bridges designed for gross vehicle road 
weights of 10 tons, well below the current standard of up to 30 tons. Bridges have often 
collapsed due to overloading. Most of the road network is dilapidated and large parts of the 
country are effectively isolated during the wet season. Most bridges are seriously damaged or 
failed. The Ministry of Public Works and Transport (MPWT) considers that at least half of the 
primary road network and nearly all the secondary and tertiary roads are in need of urgent 
repair, rehabilitation, or reconstruction. Road condition surveys in 2002 confirm that 28% of the 
network is in good or fair condition, 35% in poor condition, 28% in bad condition, and 6% under

potholes, edge failures, and pavement failures. The Government recognizes that the poor state

emphasizes the urgency of reestablishing the country’s transport infrastructure. The ongoing 
National Road Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Program aims to rehabilitate 1,400 km of 
national roads by the year 2003, thus ensuring that approximately 44% of the national road

maintenance and rehabilitation of the primary and secondary road network is estimated at 
approximately $79.0 million per year, of which the Government provides approximately 20% and 
international sources the remainder. However, bringing the primary and secondary road network 
into a fully functional and maintainable state within the foreseeable future will require increased 
levels of investment—and maintenance funding—over the next 15–20 years.

and other light vehicles by an average of 16%.

5.  A significant concern in Cambodia is the overloading of trucks, which leads to premature 
deterioration of road pavements and threatens the stability of the many bridges designed for 
light traffic. The legal axle load in Cambodia is 10 tons. There is evidence that some trucks, 
particularly those carrying cement, take on as much as 60 tons over a truck-trailer combination. 
A survey carried out in 1997 identified an average axle weight of 10 tons with maximum axle 
weights of up to 16 tons. Enforcement of axle load limits in Cambodia is weak, and it is essential 
to formulate an effective axle load control program to lead to greatly extended pavement life and 
lower bridge-maintenance costs. This is particularly important for bridges, which constitute a 
very large part of the network, as the passage of an exceptionally heavy vehicle could damage 
the structure irreparably. 
 
6.  Subdecree 744, Maximum Load Limit of Transport Vehicles Using the Road Network in 
Cambodia, was approved by the Government on 3 September 1999. The Subdecree details the

discourage overloading. Pavement design is based on the fact that vehicle damage to a road 
depends entirely on the axle load of those vehicles. The penalties listed in the Subdecree 
increase  only  linearly  with  increasing  loads,  but  damage  to  the  road  in  reality  increases 
exponentially as the load increases. Small increases in axle load above the legal limit of 10 tons 
can result in a severe increase in damage to the road pavement. As far as practicable, penalties 
should reflect the exponential increase in damage.

C.  Financial and Institutional Sustainability of the Road Sector 
1.  Road Maintenance Management and Financing 
9.  In 2000 and 2001, MPWT’s expenditures on the primary and secondary road network 
(the national and provincial roads) averaged approximately $12.5 million per year, of which 20% 
($2.5 million) were recurrent expenditures for routine maintenance, and 80% ($10.0 million) 
were capital expenditures for repair and rehabilitation of pavements. Annual average external 
agency funding added an estimated $60.0 million for road rehabilitation and improvement; the 
Government’s  expenditures  for  counterpart  funding  of  externally  financed  projects  was 
approximately $6.0 million equivalent, making for total maintenance and rehabilitation funding of 
$79.0 million. No new funds are being expended on the construction of new roads. 
 
10.  The  management  of  a  road  network  must  be  based  on  business  principles,  using 
economic  criteria  to  prioritize  and  schedule  maintenance  works.  An  asset  management 
approach is most appropriate as a long-term goal for maintaining and preserving the road 
network.  In  Cambodia’s  situation,  this  implies  a  move  from  the  present  crisis-response 
management mode to a network management mode as the core network stabilizes and normal 
periodic maintenance works can be scheduled in a cost-effective manner. Essential to that 
approach is the establishment of the maintenance management system with its basic building 
blocks that include a road and bridge inventory, a system for updating the inventory and 
accompanying condition surveys, and application of evaluation tools to prioritize and schedule 
periodic maintenance. An ADB-financed study4 has developed a decentralized approach to road 
condition monitoring, and the programming and management of routine maintenance that is 
suitable  for  implementation  by  provincial  public  works  departments.  The  study  initiated 
implementation  of  the  maintenance  management  system  in  three  pilot  provinces,  with  the 
system now being adopted by MPWT for replication in the remaining provinces of Cambodia. 
The system is based on a relatively straightforward road condition assessment procedure that 
involves  (i) vehicle  operating  speeds  and  travel  time,  (ii) drainage  considerations,  and 
(iii) engineering judgment. 
 
11.  To ensure an effective and sustainable planning and programming process, it is clearly 
essential to ensure security of funding and reliable cash flow with the attendant technical and 
financial  audit  instruments.  MPWT  has  two  sources  of  funding  for  maintenance  and 
development of the road network: general funds from the annual budget, and special funds

rehabilitation. The investment budget is retained by the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) 
and  disbursed  on  a  project  basis.  When  the  FRMR  was  established  in  2000,  it  required

which limits the scope for collection of higher vehicle and fuel taxes. These constraints will

management  and  development  of  the  transport  sector,  the  current  legal  and  regulatory

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 
 
The key contribution of the infrastructure sector is to strengthen linkages between rural and urban areas and between 
different regions of the country to promote economic growth and development activities that are geographically

The majority of the poor in Cambodia live in rural areas and base their livelihoods on agricultural activities. Many of 
the poor face food shortages for several months and are vulnerable to external shocks due to reliance on subsistence 
agriculture and deprived access to social services. Improved infrastructure will lead to increased openness for 
communities  deprived  of  adequate  access  to  information  and  markets.  This  will  increase  access  to  off-farm 
employment and diversification of risk and vulnerability. Access to markets will reduce vulnerability to food shortages 
and reliance on subsistence agriculture. Enhanced access will also enable the Government and external financing

B.  Poverty Analysis  Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
Socioeconomic and Poverty Profile in the Project Area: 
 
The area under the proposed Project includes the provinces of Siem Reap, Banteay Meanchey and Oddar Meanchey 
in Northwestern Cambodia. This area suffers from high incidence of poverty and has received minimal development 
assistance in the past because of war and insecurity. Owing to the security situation at the time of the implementation 
of the socioeconomic surveys, reliable poverty statistics on a comparative basis with the rest of the country are 
unavailable and the statistics presented are only indicative. Although some data indicating vulnerability exist for Siem 
Reap and Banteay Meanchey, the data for Oddar Meanchey are either merged with Siem Reap or do not exist. Given 
the more developed areas around Siem Reap, the data do not serve to adequately reflect the poverty and 
vulnerability that prevails in Oddar Meanchey. The lack of data in this province is in itself an indication of lack of 
access to Government, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and aid agencies. Due to high labor mobility, the data 
for Banteay Meanchey can be regarded as outdated, and vulnerability is likely to be underestimated for that reason. A 
detailed survey was fielded to further investigate poverty and vulnerability and likely impacts of increased access, 
through a socioeconomic survey and participatory focus group discussions. Based on survey data on poverty and 
vulnerability, the proposed classification of the Project is poverty intervention.  
 
Survey data suggest that poverty is widespread in the area with severe problems of accessibility during the rainy 
season. The WFP study indicates that no less than 60% of households suffer from food deficiency although there is 
some  scope  here  for  foraging,  hunting,  and  gathering  activities  to  supplement  precarious  livelihoods.  Most 
households find their food stocks depleted within 4 months of harvest. The overall poverty estimates for the project 
area is about 40%. However, there are significant variations, with the areas serviced by better roads displaying the 
lowest poverty level (25%), while NR56 and areas serviced by poor roads have very high poverty levels (over 60%). 
Thus, quite apart from relatively high poverty levels in the project area compared with the national situation, there are 
deep  pockets  of  extensive  poverty,  much  of  which  is  related  to  the  relative  physical  remoteness  and  poor 
infrastructure in the area. Government services, such as health and education, rarely reach the interior and tend to be 
restricted to peri-urban areas. Insecurity and lack of access have reduced the effectiveness and outreach of NGO 
activities. 
 
The vulnerability of the population in this area, and especially that of the poor, is marked by a number of factors. 
These include adverse demographic and socioeconomic conditions that include a high dependency ratio, illiteracy, 
poor access to drinking water and health facilities, and low school enrolment and attendance in comparison with the 
overall, national situation. Adult literacy is estimated at 46% compared with a national average of over 67%. The 
population with access to safe drinking water and sanitary latrines is estimated at less than 7% and 4%, respectively, 
compared with a national average of 29% and 15%, and school attendance (5–14 age group) is below 60% 
compared with 66% for the whole country. This is indicative of high opportunity costs of children to attend school and 
the need to engage children in livelihood activities. 
 
Access to credit is severely limited and savings are small, leading to frequent asset-liquidation to meet crises (most 
frequently caused by health shocks). Family spacing is nonexistent and whatever reproductive services exist are 
largely inaccessible due to the widely dispersed nature of the population and long travel distances/time needed to

reach these (especially in Oddar Meanchey).  
 
The national data related to women-headed households suggest a lower poverty incidence compared with similar 
male-headed households. This may not be true for the project area where at least one report points to the serious 
disadvantages faced by the former especially when able-bodied male labor is not available. Similarly the incidence of 
disabled persons is high in the area (2.2 per 1000 compared with the national average of 1.5). This is a reflection of 
prolonged civil strife and the presence of unexploded ordnance (UXO) in the area. Further, more recently settled 
villages tend to be poorer as these are yet to establish more secure livelihood systems.  
 
Indigenous ethnic minorities are not found in the immediate project area as war and insecurity led them to move 
northeast. A few remote villages, beyond the direct influence area, have ethnic minority groups such as the Pnong 
engaged in rice farming and the Cham, found around Tonle Sap, engaged in fishing. They are not considered to be 
disadvantaged in comparison to ethnic Khmers.  
 
Livelihood security is a chief concern of the poorest 40%. They are primarily subsistence farmers growing one (rain-
fed) crop a year, often of low quality or yields (which are significantly lower than those in similar agro-ecological 
areas). Irrigation is scarce and unreliable.  
 
Migration 
 
Due to its proximity to Thailand, the area is prone to labor mobility, both inward and outward. A large number of 
people migrate to the towns and to Thailand in search of work, usually illegally. They migrate for mainly economic 
reasons, in response to wage differentials between Thailand and Cambodia, food shortages and underemployment. 
Most of the migrants are poor or very poor with inadequate landholdings. Short-term migration takes place in 
response to underemployment during off-peak agricultural seasons and serves as a coping mechanism for food 
insecurity. The majority are women who work just across the border. Long-term migrants, the majority of whom are 
men, belong to households with sufficient assets to finance their trips. They travel deep into Thailand and engage in 
unskilled employment activities such as construction work, manufacturing and food processing activities. While 
migration is risky and can cause problems for those left behind, many report positive outcomes and migration is 
judged to be good for the development of skills.  
 
Migration to the area has occurred in response to internal displacement, prevailing poverty and landlessness in other 
areas, and the search for hope of better opportunities. This is evident in the area around Poipet, which has seen a 
rapid increase in the size of its population, from 30,000 in 2000 to over 100,000 in 2002. The town has grown largely 
in response to the casinos established on the Cambodian side. This has led to a rapid increase in urban poverty. A 
similar trend is emerging in the border town of O’smach in Oddar Meanchey. Newly settled households tend to be 
more vulnerable, lack social cohesion, and are more likely to live in poverty than older and more established settlers. 
 
HIV/STI 
The Cambodian Demographic Health Survey, 2000 reveals that Banteay Meanchey is one of the provinces with the 
lowest level of awareness of AIDS, with 79% of respondents aware of HIV/AIDS compared with the national average 
of 95% awareness. A 2000 HIV surveillance testing in Banteay Meanchey found the following rates of HIV positive 
people in the groups tested: 7.3% of police, 37.3% of direct commercial sex workers, 13.3% of indirect sex workers, 
and 4% of pregnant women attending antenatal clinics. While this is a decrease from previous years, it is still very 
high. The merged data for Siem Reap/Oddar Meanchey show that awareness is in line with the national average. But 
for Oddar Meanchey this is likely to be a significant overestimation. All three provinces rank low in terms of women’s 
knowledge of HIV/STD prevention. 
 
Expected Impacts on Poverty and Vulnerability  
The impacts on the poor in the project area would largely depend on how national roads 6 and 5 are linked to the 
local road network. To maximize the impacts, the proposed Project includes road improvements and all-weather 
accessibility along national roads 68 and 56, which form a loop in Oddar Meanchey. The loop will feed directly into 
the ADB-financed Northwestern Rural Development Project1 (NRDP) and enhance the joint poverty impacts of both 
national roads 6 and 5 under the proposed Project and the impacts identified under NRDP. Thus, the proposed 
Project intends to provide an integrated approach linking feeder roads (under NRDP) with provincial roads and the 
national roads. This would increase the poverty reduction impacts of both the NRDP and the proposed developments 
on national roads 6 and 5.

Recent studies of the impact of feeder roads show that the competitiveness of transport facilities is an important

Together with increased access to a wider range of employment activities labor-intensive road construction and local 
maintenance contracts provide off-farm employment opportunities that are key to poverty reduction. This is especially 
important for the landless and for those with inadequate land resources. International Labour Organization (ILO) 
studies show that nearly 47% of road workers are women. Local employment opportunities will reduce the need for 
migration to Thailand, and thus reduce vulnerability for those left behind. Thus, by incorporating local labor contracts

Social Risks 
 
One of the major objectives of the proposed Project is to enhance economic integration, increase mobility and intra- 
and cross-border trade. While labor mobility is already high, mobility can be expected to increase both to and from

Labor-Based Appropriate Technologies 
 
There are a number of poverty-oriented gaps in the current road program. First, there is a need to connect the 
primary and the rural roads with secondary roads. Second, there is a need to develop more opportunities for and 
capacity of domestic private contractors who are capable and equipped to take on construction and maintenance 
work on the national and provincial roads. Third, more research needs to be done on road technologies best suited to 
Cambodia in terms of directly and indirectly achieving poverty reduction goals, including compilation and review of 
experiences from other countries. Finally, there is a need for greater capacity for the training of engineers, public 
sector officials, and private sector contractors and consultants in road technologies and management. A project 
concept, Mainstreaming Poverty Reducing Approaches into the National Road Network, has been developed for 
grant financing under the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction to reduce poverty by refining pro-poor appropriate 
technological solutions recently developed in Cambodia, and mainstreaming them into the road programs of the 
Ministry of Public Works and Transport, and the Ministry of Rural Development. The Project will work toward 
maximizing the input of local entrepreneurs, materials, labor, and ingenuity. Thus, there is expected to be both an 
immediate direct effect on income through employment and a long-term direct effect through the provision of cost-
effective tools for the management of the road network.

3.  The road linking Siem Reap and Poipet is situated at about 10 meters (m) above sea

4.   The  climate  of  the  area  is  characterized  by  a  distinct  wet  and  dry  season.  The

slight seasonal effect lowers the temperature to 30 degrees Centigrade in December. Average 
rainfall is 1,400–1,500 mm at Siem Reap with about 80% of the rainfall in the wet season. 
 
5.  The hydrology of the area is dominated by three systems, namely (i) the hydrological 
conditions of the upper catchment areas of the Chuor Phnum Dangrek, (ii) locally derived 
drainage that originates from the main water courses and enters the Tonle Sap, and (iii) the 
operation of the Tonle Sap itself. In normal years, the Tonle Sap operates within the levels of 
1.1 m asl and 10.0 m asl. As the road is set about 10.0 m asl, parts of the road that cross the 
plain at or below this level are influenced.

8.  According to the draft subdecree on management of natural protection prepared by the 
Ministry of Environment (MOE), development projects can be implemented in the protected 
landscape areas, except for core areas. However, the BCPL has never been surveyed nor 
demarcated so the location of the core area is unknown. According to a study undertaken by the 
provincial department of environment, no rare or endangered species have been reported within 
the BCPL. 
 
9.  The Tonle Sap is the largest freshwater lake in Southeast Asia. It covers an area of 
approximately 250,00 ha in the dry season, and it extends to 1,000,000 ha during the wet 
season. NR6 borders the transition zone of Tonle Sap Multiple Use Area between Siem Reap 
and Sisophon. In the transition zone, a variety of activities are allowed without causing adverse 
environmental impacts.  
 
10.  The road crosses a floodplain that is linked to the upper part of the Tonle Sap. Both the 
floodplain and the Tonle Sap are essential and linked components of the fisheries of the area. 
Over 200 species of fish are found in the Tonle Sap with 100 species regularly occurring in the 
fish catches. The huge wetland system with its habitat diversity supports one of the most 
productive fisheries in Asia.  
 
3.  Human and Economic Development 
11.  Rice and fish are important parts of the diet for people living in the project area. Rice 
cultivation is the dominant agricultural activity. Ponds located along the roads are utilized for 
irrigation and as duck ponds. In some areas along NR56, fruit trees and maize are planted. 
 
D.  Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
1.  Drainage 
12.  The project area between Siem Reap and Sisophon is sometimes inundated in the wet 
season. The raising of an embankment between Siem Reap and Sisophon to a flood-free height 
will cause additional runoff to be held behind the embankment that will require an engineering 
solution  in  terms  of  additional  cross-flow  discharge  capacity  to  be  incorporated  within  the 
embankment.  This  may  be  achieved  by  widening  the  existing  bridges  and  culverts  or 
constructing additional cross-drainage through the road embankment. 
 
13.  The provision of additional cross-drainage will relieve water height that may build up 
against the embankment and if correctly designed, additional cross-drainage may maintain the 
flood  level  at  the  same  height  on  both  sides  of  the  embankment.  In  areas  where  rice  is 
cultivated,  improved  drainage  gives  landholders  better  access  to  their  paddy  fields  and 
increased rice production. In order to facilitate drainage of floodwater, additional culverts are 
necessary for cross-drainage. In the project area, erosion may not be significant due to the 
hydrology in the area. However, good construction practices will be implemented to avoid 
unnecessary sedimentation and water pollution.

2.  Fisheries 
14.  Most of the fish species that are found in and around the Tonle Sap do not have 
migratory patterns because the flood period is too short for breeding while others have definite 
migratory preferences. They will move into flooded plain areas once these areas are inundated, 
moving in during August or September and moving back to the Tonle Sap in October. The fish 
will move up the natural water courses and, as the floodplain is inundated, the fish will move into 
the plain for feeding and breeding. 
 
15.  The road crosses a floodplain that is of significance to fish movement, not within the 
rivers  that  are  the  primary  migration  routes  but  in  the  secondary  migration  areas  on  the 
floodplain itself. As the road will be raised and equipped with additional cross-drainage, the 
access for fish migration within the floodplain area will be restored or improved. 
 
3.  Noise and Dust 
16.  Noise  and  dust  from  unpaved  roads  are  a  major  nuisance  for  roadside  residents, 
especially those in built-up areas. As traffic flows increase, this problem will get worse until road 
surfaces are paved. The Project will have positive impacts on the quality of life of roadside 
residents as it will result in a significant reduction in noise and dust generated. 
 
17.  However, during the construction stage, mitigation measures against noise and dust are 
necessary. In order to reduce impacts by noise: (i) construction activities will be avoided at night 
close to residents, and (ii)  contractors’ vehicles will be equipped with mufflers. In order to 
minimize dust: (i)  the construction sites will be watered several times a day depending on the 
condition,  and  (ii) the  pavement  of  the  road  will  start  from  built-up  areas  to  minimize  the 
numbers of inhabitants affected by dust. 
 
4.  Construction Materials 
18.  Borrow pits will need to be located along the roads as a source of subbase material. 
Borrow pits will be left in a safe condition or restored as close as possible to a productive use. It 
is recommended that some of them be located on adjoining private land where they could be 
used as fish or duck ponds or for irrigation. 
 
19.  Gravel and crushed stone will be hauled by trucks to the project sites. There may be a 
tendency to overload the trucks, and several bridges along NR5 to Sisophon are already 
severely  damaged.  To  avoid  further  bridge  deterioration  during  reconstruction,  it  will  be 
necessary  to  ensure  that  the  contractors’  haulage  trucks  do  not  exceed  the  bridge  and 
pavement limits. In that way, dust from the trucks will also be reduced. 
 
20.  The bridge design recommends the use of precast concrete beams that would be cast in 
a specialized concrete manufacturers’ site. The beams are then transported to site and erected. 
Thus apart from the bridge abutments and possibly for large box culverts, quantities of cement 
and aggregate that would normally have been brought on site will be significantly reduced. 
 
21.  Fuels and oil storage areas should be located well away from any water courses and be 
provided with interceptor traps so that accidental spills do not contaminate the environment. All 
waste oil should be stored and disposed of to acceptable oil industry standards. Washing-down 
water also needs to be directed into this system and held in retention areas for treatment.

5.  Cleanup of the Construction Site 
22.  When construction is completed, the contractors must clean up the construction site by 
removing all equipment and buildings and carrying out site remediation work. 
 
6.  Health and Safety 
23.  The main risks during the construction stage may arise from (i) inadequate sanitation 
facilities in work camps, (ii) lack of preparation for accidents and injuries, (iii) introduction of 
sexually transmitted or other infections by immigrant workers, and (iv) outbreaks of malaria in 
the labor force. In order to avoid these risks, (i) the camps will be located a certain distance from 
communities; (ii) the contractor will prepare a worker health and safety plan, including provision 
of sanitation facilities, equipment, and medical care; (iii) workers will receive health and safety 
training; and (iv) workers will under go pre-employment health screening.  
 
E.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Program 
24.  The  Project  complies  with  procedures  set  out  by  MOE  on  environmental  review 
processes. The implementation of the IEE can be carried out by the Project Unit of MPWT 
together with the social and environment division that will be established within the Ministry. 
MPWT will develop a detailed environmental management plan (EMP) based on the IEE. 
MPWT, construction supervision consultants, and contractors will implement EMP. 
 
25.  During the detailed design stage, close consultations will be made with relevant line 
ministries such as MOE, the Ministry of Water Resources and Meteorology on drainage, and the 
Ministry of Agriculture, Fishery and Forestry on irrigation. 
 
26.  A project management unit (PMU) will carry out environmental monitoring together with 
the  construction  supervision  consultant,  and  the  results  will  be  reported  to  the  social  and 
environment division to be established in the repositioned Department of Planning. The results 
will also be incorporated in the quarterly project progress reports submitted to ADB.  
 
F.  Findings and Recommendations 
27.  The environmental screening process for the Project indicates that overall negative 
environmental impacts are deemed to be minor because: 
(i)  the Project comprises rehabilitation and resurfacing of the existing roads with 
limited realignment; 
(ii)  resettlement impacts are limited; 
(iii)  careful consideration has been given to avoiding environmental impacts along 
the project road; and 
(iv)  measures are readily available to mitigate potential impacts. 
 
G.  Conclusion 
28.  Mitigation  measures  have  been  identified  to  address  potential  impacts.  The  IEE, 
therefore, is considered sufficient and with implementation of the environmental management 
plan is considered to have complied with ADB’s environmental assessment requirements.
